Wolfe is a plain scala library (that uses Scala Macros to optimize compilation). 
This means that you can directly integrate Wolfe into your existing scala code. 
We also provide support for creating Wolfe projects from scratch. If you
aren't a Scala developer (and aren't inclined to become one), you may use
such projects to load and write into text files that can feed your non-Scala
code. Notice that Scala code runs in the JVM and can be accessed from Java code as well.

To use Wolfe in an [sbt](http://www.scala-sbt.org/) project add the following lines
to your `build.sbt` file (in case of a Build class adapt accordingly).
```
 resolvers += "Wolfe Release" at 
   "http://homeniscient.cs.ucl.ac.uk:8081/nexus/content/repositories/releases"
   
 libraryDependencies += "ml.wolfe" %% "wolfe-core" % "[VERSION]"
```
The newest version can be read (and downloaded) from the 
[release list](https://github.com/wolfe-pack/wolfe/releases).

To create a wolfe project that includes the correct dependencies and some
example code to start with, run
```
$ g8 wolfe-pack/wolfe 
```
This will prompt for a project name, and then generate an sbt project you can extend. 
You can edit this project using your favourite scala editor. You can create a 
[Intellij Idea](http://www.jetbrains.com/idea/) project using 
```
$ sbt gen-idea
```
If you want to work with Wolfe interactively, type
```
$ sbt console
```
and start hacking away.

If you like to extend Wolfe clone or fork it from [here](https://github.com/wolfe-pack/wolfe). 
To build Wolfe and publish your version to your local ivy directory, cd into 
the Wolfe home directory and type
```
$ sbt publish-local
```
